But may you never have to test the truth of all this 1 Ι should pray to the gods for that, had they not ceased to listen to any prayers of mine. How- ever, Ι do pray that they may rest content with these endless calamities of ours—calamities in which, after all, not only is there no dishonouring taint of wrong- doing, but in which is concentrated all that there is of anguish, since what was done for the best has been visited with the heaviest penalty.

As to my daughter (who is yours), and my little 10 Cicero, why should I commend them to you, my own brother? Not but that I grieve that their bereavement willcause you no less sorrow than myself.
